newsitem.title: USA: Harvard Industries files for bankruptcy.
newsitem.headline: Harvard Industries files for bankruptcy.

text.p: Harvard Industries Inc and nine affiliates, including Doehler-Jarvis Inc, filed for Chapter 11 protection on Thursday in the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Delaware, a court spokeswoman said.
Harvard's Chairman, John Adams, said the action was precipitated by continued operating losses at the company's Doehler-Jarvis subsidiary, and the need to reorganize its capital structure.

"We believe this filing to be a prudent action, which will ultimately ease Harvard's debt burden, increase the company's liquidity, and permit us to focus on our highly successful core businesses," Adams said.

Harvard has secured a commitment for $175 million in Debtor-In-Possession financing, which includes the pre-petition facility, enabling it to support continuing operations at its subsidiaries, pay its suppliers on an ongoing basis, and continue prompt delivery of automotive components to customers.
Harvard did not identify the source of the D-I-P financing.
"We intend to propose full payment to our suppliers as part of our plan, and expect to emerge from the process with substantially reduced debt," Adams said.
"Harvard Industries is open for business today and will be in the future. We intend to meet our obligations to our customers, our vendors, our employees and our shareholders ...."
The company listed assets of $478.6 million and liabilities of $708.1 million, of which $598.1 million is in fixed, liquidated unsecured debt with 12,000 holders, court papers say.
Court papers describe at least $300 million of the debt as 12 percent senior notes due 2004 and 11-1/8 percent senior notes due 2005.
Court papers say "the obligations of Harvard Industries Inc under the 12- and 11-1/8 percent senior notes are guaranteed by each of its debtor subsidiaries."
Harvard Industries is an original equipment manufacturer of automotive parts and accessories.
